author: By Erika Solomon
title: History Haunts Ukraine’s Undiplomatic Voice in Berlin
description: Debate over a Ukrainian nationalist leader’s role in the Holocaust has exposed how views of the past shape European allies’ relationships with Kyiv.
content: BERLIN — It was as if Ukraine’s ambassador in Germany had been vying for the title of most undiplomatic diplomat: Determined to spur Berlin into more urgent support for his embattled nation, he mocked the chancellor, told a former lawmaker to “shut your trap,” and posted memes on Twitter likening Germany’s lagging weapons deliveries to a snail with a bullet taped to its back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Sussman Fischler
title: House Hunting in Panama: A Tuscan-Style Villa in the Hills of Boquete
description: The popular mountain town on the Caldera River is enticing a wider group of buyers, with remote workers joining retirees in a heated market.
content: This six-bedroom Tuscan-style mansion is secluded between two hillsides in the exclusive estate section of Valle Escondido, a high-end community, resort and club close to downtown Boquete, the mountain town nestled in the Chiriquí Highlands of western Panama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Skandha Gunasekara and Emily Schmall
title: Tear gas fired at protesters outside the prime minister’s office.
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Police and military forces used tear gas to try to disperse a growing crowd outside the office of Sri Lanka’s prime minister, who was the top leader in the country after the president fled.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Police and military forces used tear gas to try to disperse a growing crowd outside the office of Sri Lanka’s prime minister, who was the top leader in the country after the president fled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Portraits by Barkley L. Hendricks Will Hang With Old Masters at the Frick
description: He is the first artist of color to have a solo show at the 87-year-old museum, organized by Aimee Ng and Antwaun Sargent.
content: The portrait artist Barkley L. Hendricks, who died in 2017, considered the Frick Collection one of his favorite museums. Now Hendricks’s celebratory, large-scale paintings of Black Americans will hang in that institution, long the home of Rembrandt, Bronzino and Van Dyck, as the first artist of color to have a solo show at the 87-year-old Frick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $300,000 Homes in Massachusetts, West Virginia and Delaware
description: A seasonal cottage in Wellfleet, a farmhouse in Follansbee and a three-bedroom rowhouse in Wilmington.
content: This small cottage is in a seasonal colony on Cape Cod, open from April 1 to Nov. 30. Many colony residents rent out their cottages, which are especially in demand during the summer months. This house, which has propane heat and a window air-conditioning unit, is being sold furnished.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Mother’s Secret
description: He always thought his father was the only one at fault. Until one day, deep into adulthood, his mother asked him if they could go on a walk.
content: Ayad Akhtar’s parents met in Pakistan in the early ’60s, when they were both medical students and “ridiculously attractive” — or so their friends say. Despite having a love marriage (against the wishes of their parents), theirs was rocky from the start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: Statue of Black Educator Replaces Confederate General in U.S. Capitol
description: Mary McLeod Bethune is the first Black American to be represented with a state statue in the National Statuary Hall. Her likeness replaces a statue honoring one of the last Confederate generals to surrender.
content: Mary McLeod Bethune on Wednesday became the first Black American to be represented with a state statue in National Statuary Hall, a central room of the United States Capitol, honored for her work championing education and civil rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ava Sasani
title: Suspect Is Arrested in Ohio After Rape of 10-Year-Old Girl
description: The case became a flash point in the abortion debate after the young victim was forced to travel out of state for the procedure.
content: An Ohio man has been arrested and charged with the rape of a 10-year-old girl, whose travel across state lines to receive an abortion captured national attention.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Stunning New Peek Into the Ancient Cosmos
description: Quotation of the Day for July 14, 2022.
content: “I’m gobsmacked.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: It Really Wasn’t Cricket: The Strange Case of the Fake Indian Premier League
description: The bats and balls were real, but not much else was authentic in what officials said was an elaborate scheme to dupe Russian gamblers through hoax games streamed on YouTube.
content: There were floodlights, high-definition cameras and umpires with walkie-talkies pinned to their shoulders. The cricket players wore colorful uniforms. The broadcast had the voices of recognized commentators, and the logo of the globally recognized television channel: the BBC.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Bad Planning and Errors, Not Fans, Led to Champions League Chaos, Report Says
description: A French Senate inquiry faulted the authorities for blaming large crowds of supporters instead of owning up to their failures, after violence and confusion marred a final near Paris.
content: PARIS — Faulty coordination, bad planning and multiple errors by French authorities were responsible for the chaos that marred this year’s Champions League soccer final just outside Paris, according to a parliamentary report published on Wednesday that criticized officials for blaming English fans instead of acknowledging their own failings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Sri Lanka’s Leader Flees
description: Plus President Biden visits Israel, and negotiations continue over Ukraine’s blocked grain.
content: For hours yesterday, it was not clear who was in charge of Sri Lanka.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Phoebe Robinson Is Trash, and She’s Fine With It
description: Robinson created and stars in “Everything’s Trash,” a new series that “is a celebration of people who aren’t in a rush to change who they are,” she said.
content: “Everyone is trash,” Phoebe Robinson explained. “We all have our great qualities, but we also have flaws. Sometimes they’re lovable. Sometimes they’re not. And it’s OK.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Siegel
title: What’s Really Going on in Those Police Fentanyl Exposure Videos?
description: It’s nearly impossible for an overdose to be caused by brief contact with the drug. It is possible these videos will worsen the danger for those truly at risk.
content: For the past five years, I’ve watched a bizarre news cycle play out on repeat. The most recent recurrence began on June 16, when KCTV5, a local news organization in Kansas City, Mo., published police body-camera footage under a dramatic headline: “ ‘I Knew I Was Dying’: How 5 Rounds of Narcan Possibly Saved KCK Police Officer’s Life.” The operative word in that sentence is “possibly.” The footage shows a police officer standing on a snowy lawn in what looks like a suburban neighborhood, wearing sunglasses and disposable gloves, inspecting pills stashed inside a crumpled piece of paper. “Seal it up — that’s fentanyl, dude,” another officer says. “Get that in a bag quick, so we don’t have an exposure.” The time stamp on the video then jumps to five minutes later. The officer who held the pills is now collapsed on the ground, limbs splayed as though making a snow angel. We hear another officer yell, “Narcan, Narcan, Narcan!” The fallen officer gasps rapidly as his fellow officers, with what seems like genuine panic, spray the opioid-overdose antidote up his nose several times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israelis prepare for the traffic snarl of the decade.
description: JERUSALEM — Many of Jerusalem’s main thoroughfares are festooned with American flags in honor of President Biden’s visit, but that’s not all. Every few yards, notices warn the public of sporadic closure of the roads for the three-day duration of the visit.
content: JERUSALEM — Many of Jerusalem’s main thoroughfares are festooned with American flags in honor of President Biden’s visit, but that’s not all. Every few yards, notices warn the public of sporadic closure of the roads for the three-day duration of the visit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Twitter Unloads on Musk
description: The company contends that Musk breached his agreement to buy it by not using “reasonable best efforts” to close the deal, and so has no right to bail out.
content: Twitter filed a much-anticipated lawsuit yesterday as it looks to force Elon Musk to close his $44 billion acquisition of the company. Twitter argues that it has every right to do so under a specific performance provision in the deal contract.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: What It Means to Raise an American Girl Now
description: When straightforward progress no longer feels inevitable.
content: One of the images that have stuck with me from the pandemic’s early days is the doll hospital my daughters made from cardboard boxes. Not long after their world was locked down, my children’s American Girl dolls were afflicted with an unnamed illness and put to bed for weeks. My own girls, who were 7 and 3 at the time, took their self-appointed jobs as doll nurses very seriously, and would frequently check on their patients, keeping me and my husband apprised of their progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: How the Colorful Costumes of ‘Thor: Love and Thunder’ Were Made
description: “The Phantom of the Opera,” “Big Trouble in Little China” and an archaeology museum all played a part, the designer Mayes Rubeo explains.
content: There is a hush-hush building in North Hollywood full of supersuits and scraps, a costume warehouse where Marvel Studios preserves every major outfit that its heroes have worn onscreen during the last decade and a half. For the costume designer Mayes Rubeo, touring the warehouse is always a fun trip, not least because there is an aisle of costume leftovers from her work on “Thor: Ragnarok” that comprises the most colorful section of the entire building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: The Saga of a World War II Ancestor of Miss Piggy, Bert and Yoda
description: Long before Frank Oz brought many Muppets to life, his father, an amateur Dutch puppeteer, made a Hitler marionette as an act of defiance. He buried it during the war.
content: The puppet stands 20 inches tall, hand-painted and carved out of wood, its uniform tattered and torn. But for all it has endured over more than 80 years — buried in a backyard in Belgium at the outset of World War II, dug up after the war and taken on a nine-day cross-Atlantic journey, stored and almost forgotten in an attic in Oakland, Calif. — it remains, with its black toothbrush mustache and right arm raised in a Nazi salute, immediately and chillingly recognizable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Rob Szypko, Rachelle Bonja, Carlos Prieto, Michael Simon Johnson, John Ketchum, Paige Cowett, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Could the Midterms Be Tighter Than Expected?
description: A new New York Times poll suggests a surprisingly close race for the control of Congress.
content: For months, leaders of the Democratic Party and President Biden have been bracing for huge losses in the upcoming midterm elections. Today, “The Daily” explores a new New York Times poll that complicates that thinking — and could set the stage for a very different showdown in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Sokol
title: The Lonely Work of Picking the Universe’s Best Astronomy Pictures
description: In June, specialists gathered in Baltimore to select images from the James Webb Space Telescope to share with the public. Keeping the results to themselves hasn’t been easy.
content: BALTIMORE — After the image flashes up on the projector, a few quiet beats tick by, punctuated only by a soft “wow.” Everyone is processing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Leiby
title: Please Laugh About My Abortion With Me
description: Amid the grief over Roe v. Wade, comedy can be a coping mechanism.
content: On Friday evening, June 24, I arrived at the Cherry Lane Theater in Manhattan having already traveled between outrage, exhaustion and despair. Roe v. Wade was overturned that morning, and I was about to perform my comedy show “Oh God, a Show About Abortion.” I performed the show after the draft of the Supreme Court decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization leaked, and the mood in the theater then was somber; an edgier joke, one that normally elicits reluctant bursts of laughter, earned groans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Netflix turns to Microsoft to help build its new ad-supported service.
description: The streaming giant hopes a less expensive offering will boost subscription numbers, which have dropped for the first time in a decade.
content: Netflix has selected Microsoft to help build its forthcoming ad-supported tier, the streaming giant said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman and Damon Winter
title: Gerrymander, U.S.A.
description: The way we designed our system of political representation incentivizes the worst and most extreme elements of our politics.
content: The downtown of Denton, Texas, a city of about 150,000 people and two large universities just north of Dallas, exudes the energy of a fast-growing place with a sizable student population: There’s a vibrant independent music scene, museums and public art exhibits, beer gardens, a surfeit of upscale dining options, a weekly queer variety show. The city is also racially and ethnically diverse: More than 45 percent of residents identify as Latino, Black, Asian or multiracial. There aren’t too many places in Texas where you can encounter Muslim students praying on a busy downtown sidewalk, but Denton is one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Cardinal Cláudio Hummes, Close Ally of Pope Francis, Dies at 87
description: An advocate for the poor, he was a force behind the progressive turn taken by many Latin American Catholics in the 1970s and ’80s.
content: Cardinal Cláudio Hummes, a Brazilian prelate in the Roman Catholic Church whose blend of doctrinal conservatism and social progressivism allowed him to move easily between the impoverished slums of Rio de Janeiro and the inner sanctums of the Vatican, especially during the tenure of his close friend Pope Francis, died on July 4 at his residence in São Paulo. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Here is how Sri Lanka reached this moment of crisis.
description: In recent months, Sri Lanka has run out of food and fuel, prompting a swelling protest movement. Here’s a timeline of how the situation has unfolded.
content: Sri Lanka, an island nation of 22 million people, was once held up as an economic success story, with a rising middle class and one of the highest median incomes in South Asia. But the country is now essentially out of money, and many people are living on the edge, a result of poor political decisions, reckless spending and economic mismanagement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Five Things Learned From the Webb Telescope’s First Images
description: There is a lot more universe out there to see than there was before the telescope launched, and there is so much more to explain.
content: NASA on Tuesday released five images from the early work of the James Webb Space Telescope. The pictures highlighted the great potential of the telescope to plumb the secrets of deep space. Below are some of the things we have learned so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: The movement to remove the president started with a candlelight vigil.
description: The goals are disparate and there are no clear leaders. The protesters included students and trade unionists, Catholic nuns and Buddhist monks, farmers and middle-class professionals.
content: They came in buses, in trains, on bicycles, and on foot. Some have camped on a public beach in Colombo for months, while others rustled up scant fuel supplies to reach the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Michael Levenson
title: A Tech Executive Is Charged, for the Third Time, in a 1992 Killing
description: After new forensic evidence emerged, the executive was charged in the strangulation of a Bay Area computer engineer. He had been tried twice for her murder in the 1990s.
content: In the 1990s, John Kevin Woodward was tried twice on charges that he had killed his roommate’s girlfriend, a three-sport athlete in high school and computer engineer who was found strangled in her car in Mountain View, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘My Name Is Sara’ Review: Keeping Secrets in Close Quarters
description: In this intermittently powerful if somewhat stiff-jointed Holocaust drama, a Jewish girl poses as a gentile and works as a nanny for a Ukrainian farmer and his wife.
content: In the Holocaust drama “My Name Is Sara,” a Jewish girl hides out with a Ukrainian farming family and works as a nanny in exchange for food and shelter. Posing as a gentile, Sara (Zuzanna Surowy) tells the farmer, Pavlo (Eryk Lubos), and his wife, Nadya (Michalina Olszanska), that her name is Manya and that she has run away from a troubled home life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Hunt
title: How I Became a Pathological Liar
description: Lying is part of the “etiquette of poverty.”
content: When I was 9, my family went on a long, strange road trip. Our destination was Walt Disney World, in Orlando, Fla., and the cost of admission was a lie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and Ashley Gilbertson
title: How Demand for Twigs Is Bringing Down a Rainforest
description: In the Congo River Basin, people who collect bundles of wood to make charcoal are playing a surprisingly large role in the deforestation of a region that rivals the Amazon in importance.
content: Every day late in the afternoon, women lugging bags of sticks on their back spill out of the brush onto a highway just south of the Equator. Men pass on motorbikes, one after another, hauling bags of charcoal. Boys trudge along with a single log slung over their shoulders, as if they’re toting a baguette.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: A Trump Backer’s Downfall as the Target of a Jan. 6 Conspiracy Theory
description: Ray Epps became the unwitting face of an attempt by pro-Trump forces to promote the baseless idea that the F.B.I. was behind the attack on the Capitol.
content: IN THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS — Up a winding country road, in a trailer park a half-mile from a cattle ranch, lives a man whose life has been ruined by a Jan. 6 conspiracy theory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Michael Schwirtz
title: After Ukraine-Russia Meeting, U.N. Sees ‘a Ray of Hope’ to Free Grain
description: Negotiators did not reach a deal to allow grain to flow from blockaded Ukrainian ports and ease a global food crisis, but the U.N. secretary general said they made progress.
content: BRUSSELS — Russian and Ukrainian negotiators met on Wednesday in an increasingly desperate effort to release huge stores of grain blocked by Russian warships, yielding what the United Nations secretary general called “a ray of hope” but no formal agreement that could alleviate rising world hunger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Heller
title: Bidding Farewell to His Theatrical Flock
description: In a 34-year run at New York Theater Workshop, James C. Nicola held that directors and writers are equal partners — and helped send “Rent” and “Hadestown” to Broadway.
content: The Tony Awards ceremony had just wrapped up at Radio City Music Hall, and it was time for the parties. But for one honoree, James C. Nicola, the longtime artistic director of New York Theater Workshop, there would be no stop-off for toasts at the Plaza Hotel or after-midnight carousing at Tavern on the Green.

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Poll Shows Tight Race for Control of Congress as Class Divide Widens
description: Nonwhite and working-class Democrats worry more about the economy, while white college graduates focus more on issues like abortion rights and guns.
content: With President Biden’s approval rating mired in the 30s and with nearly 80 percent of voters saying the country is heading in the wrong direction, all the ingredients seem to be in place for a Republican sweep in the November midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Why Some of Your Annuals Should Be Native Plants
description: Say the word “annuals” and most gardeners think of subtropical plants like petunias or marigolds. But native annuals do so much more for your garden.
content: There it was, as flashy as in the seed-catalog photos: three-foot-tall Euphorbia marginata, the striking green-and-white variegated spurge known as snow on the mountain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sigrid Nunez
title: ‘Desperate Characters’ and the Chaos That Lies Beneath
description: Paula Fox, the author of the 1970 novel, writes Sigrid Nunez, had a keen sense of the thin veneer of civilization, and how little it takes to fall through.
content: This essay is part of T’s Book Club, a series of articles and events dedicated to classic works of American literature. Click here to R.S.V.P. to a virtual conversation about “Desperate Characters,” to be led by Sigrid Nunez and held on Aug. 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Packing Pitchforks for the Hamptons
description: Along for an early morning “billionaire wake-up call” with protesters on Meadow Lane.
content: On Tuesday morning at 5 a.m., before the day’s oysters were unloaded from their fishing boats and the first bikes churned at SoulCycle, 16 protesters showed up on East Hampton’s Further Lane, one of the mega-richest blocks in one of the country’s mega-richest enclaves. They were there to stage what they described as “billionaire wake-up calls.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: As Faith Flags in U.S. Government, Many Voters Want to Upend the System
description: Desire for structural changes cuts across both parties, a Times/Siena College poll found, but for starkly different reasons. Even Democrats now question if the government is a force for good.
content: A majority of American voters across nearly all demographics and ideologies believe their system of government does not work, with 58 percent of those interviewed for a New York Times/Siena College poll saying that the world’s oldest independent constitutional democracy needs major reforms or a complete overhaul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joy Dong
title: In Shanghai, a surge in cases raises fears of another lockdown.
description: Residents have been alarmed by mixed messages from officials, including advice that they stock up on food and medicine.
content: Barely six weeks after Shanghai fully lifted a prolonged and harshly enforced lockdown, China’s biggest city is again grappling with a surge of coronavirus cases. Residents wary of being suddenly confined in their homes have been alarmed by mixed messages from official sources circulating on social media, including advice that they stock up on food and medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Perlez
title: In Divide Over Ukraine, China Stakes a Position Further From U.S.
description: Recent statements have underscored the deep chasms in a relationship that is getting worse, as the Biden administration tries to come up with a cohesive China policy.
content: When the secretary of state, Antony J. Blinken, pressed China this weekend to ditch its support of Russia’s war in Ukraine, he was pushing up against a red line now firmly entrenched in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: How to Save an Ancient, Giant Tree From a Wildfire
description: The authorities in Yosemite National Park are hopeful that a sprinkler system can save the Grizzly Giant, a more than 200-foot-tall sequoia that dates back at least 2,000 years.
content: More than a century ago, the naturalist John Muir took President Theodore Roosevelt to camp beneath an ancient, gnarled tree in Yosemite National Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: U.S. Tells Pharmacists Not to Withhold Pills That Can Cause Abortion
description: New Biden administration guidance warned that failing to dispense such drugs “may be discriminating” on the basis of sex or disability, citing other conditions that they can treat.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration warned the nation’s 60,000 retail pharmacies on Wednesday that they risk violating federal civil rights law if they refuse to fill prescriptions for pills that can induce abortion — the second time this week that it has used its executive authority to set up showdowns with states where abortion is now illegal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Who’s the Oldest of Them All?
description: Two towns in Sardinia battle for the distinction of having the longest-living residents. One has the imprimatur of Guinness World Records.
content: PERDASDEFOGU, Sardinia — Deep in the Sardinian mountains, a sign on a winding road opposite an abandoned playground welcomes visitors to Perdasdefogu, home of the “World Record of Family Longevity.” Black-and-white portraits of the wizened locals who reached age 100 look out onto a sleepy main street near “Longevity Square.” Campaign posters promise the town’s rebirth through “DNA” and “Longevity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek Shankar
title: Why protesters demanded the president’s resignation.
description: For many Sri Lankans, food and fuel became either impossible to find or too expensive to buy.
content: One of the first signs of trouble came just before the coronavirus pandemic hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Ex-C.I.A. Engineer Convicted in Biggest Theft Ever of Agency Secrets
description: The top federal prosecutor in Manhattan said Joshua Schulte had engaged in “one of the most brazen and damaging acts of espionage in American history.”
content: A former Central Intelligence Agency software engineer was convicted by a federal jury on Wednesday of causing the largest theft of classified information in the agency’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Why City Workers in New York Are Quitting in Droves
description: Competition from the private sector and the government’s balky hiring practices have prompted thousands to flee city government.
content: New York City, the largest municipal employer in the country, is facing an exodus of city workers that has led to a surge in job vacancies and difficulties delivering basic municipal services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Sunak Takes the Lead in the Voting to Replace U.K. Prime Minister
description: The former chancellor of the Exchequer led a pack of candidates after the first round, while an obscure trade minister surprised in second place.
content: LONDON — Rishi Sunak, a former chancellor of the Exchequer, stayed at the front of the pack of candidates vying to replace Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain after the first round of the Conservative Party’s leadership contest on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel McGraw
title: A Day of Mourning in Ohio, Where a Young Black Man Was Killed by Police
description: Protesters have gathered regularly in downtown Akron since the death of Jayland Walker. The city has imposed a nightly curfew.
content: AKRON, Ohio — Hundreds of mourners filled a downtown Akron theater on Wednesday to pay their last respects to Jayland Walker, a young Black man killed by police officers, in a city that has been on edge since his death.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Joseph Smith to Salmon Farms
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: JOSEPH SMITH AND THE MORMONS, by Noah Van Sciver. (Abrams ComicArts, $29.99.) This biography covers the life of the founder of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, from his visions of an ancient record etched on gold plates to his young death at the hands of an angry mob. Van Sciver’s vivid drawings give voice to Smith’s ardent belief while also depicting moments of serious doubt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Starter Home
description: Addison Snell’s puzzle ponders the big questions.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor Addison Snell, who is making his New York Times Crossword debut today with a puzzle that is sure to delight armchair philosophers and classic cartoon buffs alike. Mr. Snell is the 46th constructor to debut in 2022 — what a time to be solving crossword puzzles!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Abramson
title: 5 Foam Rolling Exercises for Skeptics
description: Here’s what to know before adding a foam roller to your warm-up or cool down.
content: Like many people working from home during the pandemic, Veronika Javor, 39, swapped a supportive desk chair in her office for a soft sofa chair in her living room. It was comfortable at first, but the new seat soon took a toll, as Ms. Javor, a Houston-based content creator, developed a sharp, radiating pain in her left buttock. She tried to ignore it, but after a particularly tough glute-focused Pilates workout, the discomfort became unbearable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Mitt Romney Is Inventing Policies for a Fantasy G.O.P.
description: A pro-life movement that rejects a safety net for children and families is less hypocritical than it may seem.
content: Last year, as an alternative to the temporary expansion of the child tax credit under President Biden’s American Rescue Plan, Senator Mitt Romney of Utah introduced a plan to give every family a monthly benefit of up to $350 per child for children 5 and under and $250 per child for children 6 to 17. It was simple, generous (it included a payment before birth, too) and — on paper, at least — effective. According to the Niskanen Center, which helped devise the proposal, the Romney plan would cut overall child poverty by roughly a third and the deepest child poverty by half.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California Becomes First State to Move Back School Start Times
description: The state is rolling out a first-of-its kind law that delays when middle and high school classes begin.
content: Go ahead and hit that snooze button one more time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Airlines’ Challenge Is Cutting Costs, Not Filling Seats
description: U.S. carriers see no slowdown in demand, despite unease about the economy. But problems with staffing and operations are eating into profits.
content: There is little sign that higher fares or recession worries are curbing the pent-up demand for air travel. But higher expenses and staffing shortages are hampering the nation’s airlines as they seek to take full advantage of the rebound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: Computers and Painting’s Identity Crisis
description: A show at Nahmad Contemporary is an outgrowth of debates around “tradition” in art. Can artists embrace beauty while reaching for new technology?
content: Every new generation of artists, curators, and critics seems to feel the need to defend painting. It makes sense: paint on canvas, good for little else, is basically synonymous with big-A Art. Painting stands for art’s angels and demons, its optimism and attention, its arrogance and solipsism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Kingsbury
title: Reflecting on a Times Luminary
description: Francis X. Clines left a mark on this newspaper and the world around him.
content: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning and on Saturdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Steinhauer and Dawn Chan
title: Art We Saw This Summer
description: From our critics, reviews of closed gallery shows around New York City.
content: The Green-Wood Cemetery’s catacombs are small and lit only by skylights and an open door. Such conditions make it an unusual place to exhibit art, yet the setting is incredibly evocative. A few years ago, the artist Janine Antoni created work that seemed to commune with this 1850s burial building (which is mostly closed to the public). Now Heidi Lau, the cemetery’s first artist-in-residence, has done the same with “Gardens as Cosmic Terrains.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and J. David Goodman
title: Video Deepens Uvalde Families’ Pain as Questions on Response Remain
description: A delayed police response to the May 24 school shooting has been described and debated, but a new 77-minute video showing it in painful detail has rekindled outrage.
content: UVALDE, Texas — Families of those killed in a mass shooting in Uvalde, Texas, in May voiced a mix of sorrow and anger on Wednesday after seeing a video showing how armed officers stood around waiting before confronting the gunman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
title: Nukes, Oil and a Prince’s Redemption: A Trip Fraught With Perils for Biden
description: President Biden is heading to the Mideast with one eye on U.S. strategic goals abroad and another on his political vulnerabilities back home.
content: JERUSALEM — President Biden is traveling to Israel on Wednesday for a four-day trip to the Middle East to try to slow down Iran’s nuclear program, speed up the flow of oil to American pumps, and reshape the relationship with Saudi Arabia without seeming to embrace a crown prince who stands accused of flagrant human rights abuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: The BA.5 Wave
description: The most transmissible Omicron variant yet is causing a fresh wave of cases.
content: The most transmissible Omicron variant yet, BA.5, is causing a fresh wave of cases, reinfections and hospitalizations across the country. Some are calling this the “invisible wave” because it’s not registering in some of the metrics we use to track the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Florida Company Recalls Ice Cream Linked to Listeria Outbreak, F.D.A. Says
description: The recall by Big Olaf Creamery came as federal authorities are investigating its products, which have been linked to infections that led to one person’s death and the hospitalization of two dozen.
content: A Florida business is recalling its ice cream amid an investigation into a listeria outbreak that has been blamed for the death of one person and the hospitalization of two dozen, the Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Let Them Have Couture
description: Balenciaga’s latest experiment attempts to open up the mysterious world of Parisian haute couture.
content: PARIS — I spent quite a long time sniffing the candle, twisting the mirrored jar around in my hands and tilting my head, as if inhaling from different angles might yield new discoveries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Far From Kabul, Building a New Life, With Music and Hope
description: The students of the Afghanistan National Institute of Music fled after the Taliban seized power. Now they are trying to remake their school, and their dreams, in Portugal.
content: LISBON — On some nights, when her dorm room here turns dark and the church bells stop ringing, the young trumpet player thinks about the distant afternoon when her uncle took her to the graveyard to gather stones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Secret Service Employee Sent Home After Arrest in Israel
description: The employee had a “physical encounter,” a spokesman for the agency said, although it did not involve a sexual assault.
content: A Secret Service employee working in Israel before President Biden’s visit there this week was sent home late Monday after being briefly arrested by the Israeli police in what the U.S. agency called “a physical encounter,” a spokesman for the Secret Service said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Owner of Sweet & Vicious Bar Will Pay $500,000 for Worker Harassment
description: The state attorney general says employees at the Manhattan bar were subjected to repeated slurs and sexual harassment.
content: Sweet & Vicious, a downtown Manhattan bar and restaurant popular for its “jargaritas” — frozen margaritas served in giant Mason jars — has been a nest of sexual, racial and gender-based harassment where workers endured racial slurs, had tips taken by the management and went unpaid for work, according to a 16-month investigation by Letitia James, the New York State attorney general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Furious Over LIV Golf, British Open Could Change Entry Rules
description: The R&A’s chief executive issued a stark warning to the players and did little to disguise his disdain for the new Saudi-backed series.
content: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The organizer of the British Open — openly contemptuous, frustrated and bewildered over the emergence of the Saudi Arabia-backed series that has split golf — issued a warning on Wednesday: One of the world’s most hallowed tournaments might soon change its entry rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Brittney Griner and the Limits of American Power
description: For Griner, and other Americans held prisoner overseas, the road home may be long, and slow.
content: Brittney Griner is many things. A truly extraordinary basketball player. The embodiment of the promises made by feminism, generally, and Title IX, specifically, to a generation of American girls. A wealthy celebrity. An L.G.B.T. icon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish
title: Gates Foundation Adds $20 Billion to Its Coffers
description: The organization, still run by Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates, will eventually spend $9 billion a year, up from $6 billion, on causes like global health and education.
content: When the news emerged last year that Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates were divorcing, the question of whether their foundation would lose ready access to its founders’ substantial resources quickly arose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Are Your Lessons for the Next Pandemic?
description: We’re looking for your best advice for surviving a plague, no matter how big or small.
content: When we look back on the coronavirus pandemic, there were so many mistakes. Leaders initially dismissed masking as a preventive measure, testing was a total mess, and doctors and nurses spent months without the tools they needed to combat the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Why Elon Musk Can’t Back Out of Buying Twitter, According to Twitter
description: Here are some of the company’s main legal arguments.
content: In a 62-page lawsuit filed on Tuesday, Twitter accused Elon Musk of breaching an agreement to buy the social media company for $44 billion. Mr. Musk, the world’s richest man, has tried to back out of the acquisition, citing Twitter’s number of fake accounts and accusing the company of not giving him enough information about the issue and misrepresenting itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Royals Will Play Without 10 Unvaccinated Players in Toronto
description: Andrew Benintendi, Whit Merrifield and eight others will be placed on the restricted list ahead of Kansas City’s four-game series against the Blue Jays.
content: Andrew Benintendi, an All-Star outfielder and a potential trade target of multiple teams ahead of next month’s deadline, is one of 10 Kansas City Royals players who are unvaccinated against Covid-19 and will be placed on the restricted list before their team’s four-game series in Toronto that begins Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Adopts ‘No Handshake’ Covid Policy, but Not for Long
description: A virus subvariant provided a reason to “reduce contact” before a potentially fraught encounter with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia. The plan quickly slipped away in Israel.
content: JERUSALEM — That didn’t last very long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: For Blind Internet Users, the Fix Can Be Worse Than the Flaws
description: Companies say their A.I.-powered tools are the best way to fix accessibility problems online, but many blind people find they make websites harder to use.
content: Patrick Perdue, a radio enthusiast who is blind, regularly shopped for equipment through the website of Ham Radio Outlet. The website’s code allowed him to easily move through the sections of each page with his keyboard, his screen reader speaking the text.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: 45 Years Ago Tonight, a Blackout Struck New York City
description: The 1977 outage lasted 25 hours and led to looting in many neighborhoods.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look back at one of the defining moments in the city’s psyche that began 45 years ago tonight — the 1977 blackout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Gas Prices, a Big Inflation Factor, Are Coming Down Sharply
description: A four-week decline has offered some relief to drivers. Weather, war and demand will influence how long the decline lasts.
content: HOUSTON — Gasoline prices, on an upward tear for months, have reversed course in recent weeks, giving consumers a welcome break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Panel Will Turn Over Evidence on Fake Electors to the Justice Dept.
description: The department has asked the House committee investigating the Capitol attack to share transcripts regarding the false electors scheme, the only topic it has broached with the panel.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has asked the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol for evidence it has accumulated about the scheme by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies to put forward false slates of pro-Trump electors in battleground states won by Joseph R. Biden Jr. in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: The path out of this crisis goes through Parliament.
description: The spotlight is now on a parliament that has long frustrated the island nation of 22 million, with lawmakers and political parties engaging in protracted and messy fights over positions of power.
content: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s ousting, after months of protest against him and the powerful ruling dynasty, does not necessarily open an easy path for Sri Lanka out of its economic and political crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Russia’s oil war with the West.
content: As Russia pushes to find new buyers for its oil amid tough Western sanctions, it is cutting into the market shares of two of its allies — Iran and Venezuela — and setting off a price war that could hurt them all. Experts expect that if the oil battle intensifies, it will raise tensions with the Kremlin even as Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, works to shore up his alliances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Works With Arab Allies to Down Drones, in Sign of Growing Ties
description: The destruction of Iranian drones last year was an early example of a new regional military project that President Biden is trying to shore up during his Middle East visit.
content: TEL AVIV — In the skies east of Israel, a few minutes before 2 a.m., four Israeli pilots scanned the horizon for two unmanned aircraft that were heading toward Israel from Iran. Suddenly, the pilots saw them — two triangular drones, each roughly eight yards wide, speeding westward.
source.name: The New York Times

title: President Rajapaksa arrives in the Maldives.
description: Sri Lanka’s president, Gotabaya Rajapaksa, has fled to the Maldives, whose leaders have close ties with the president and his family.
content: Sri Lanka’s president, Gotabaya Rajapaksa, has fled to the Maldives, whose leaders have close ties with the president and his family.

content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: This Trumpeter’s Legacy Also Includes Composing String Quartets
description: A new boxed set of string quartets by Wadada Leo Smith, an anchor of American experimental music, reveals his sustained engagement with the form.
content: The trumpeter Wadada Leo Smith has played an outsize role in American experimental music for the last 50 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins and Carl Zimmer
title: Novavax’s latecomer Covid-19 vaccine gets U.S. authorization.
description: The vaccine was authorized as a primary immunization series for adults, rather than a booster, which may limit its market at first.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday authorized a Covid-19 vaccine developed by Novavax, a biotechnology company in Maryland that received significant federal funding to produce the shot. The vaccine will be a new option for Americans as vaccination rates stagnate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
title: Biden’s Saudi trip is framed as centering on national security, but oil is the most urgent factor.
description: For public consumption, the White House has argued that President Biden’s decision to go to Saudi Arabia was driven by a whole range of national security issues, not just oil. But oil is in fact the most urgent reason for the trip at a time of high gas prices.
content: For public consumption, the White House has argued that President Biden’s decision to go to Saudi Arabia was driven by a whole range of national security issues, not just oil. But oil is in fact the most urgent reason for the trip at a time of high gas prices.

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: 3 Charged With Hate Crimes After Racist Tracts Flood Small New York City
description: A white supremacist leaflet was reported to the Hornell police early Sunday. Before long, similar material was found all over town.
content: The first report that someone was spreading white supremacist literature in Hornell, N.Y., came to the police early Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: A Mysterious Fall Was the First Sign Something Was Wrong
description: What felt like a shove brought her to her knees. It wasn’t until a year later that an ultrasound revealed the cause — and rushed her into surgery.
content: “OK, let’s go,” the hairdresser cheerfully instructed the 67-year-old woman reclining at the hair-washing basin. The woman rose, her hair swathed in a fluffy towel, but at the first step she stumbled. She smiled, a little embarrassed, and looked behind her. Did someone bump into her? As she reached the doorway to the room of mirrors and styling chairs, the woman again felt a shove. This time it sent her up against the doorway, and she dropped to her knees. The hairdresser grabbed her arm and steadied her. “You OK?” she asked, helping the woman to her feet. “I guess so,” the older woman answered. But she hadn’t been, for those two brief moments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Twist on the Mountain: Vingegaard Grabs Tour de France Lead
description: A daring attack near the end of a punishing stage put a Danish rider in the yellow jersey, left Tadej Pogacar in his wake and upended the standings.
content: Jonas Vingegaard turned the Tour de France on its head on Wednesday with a sharp attack on the brutal final climb that won him the race’s 11th stage and snatched the leader’s yellow jersey from Tadej Pogacar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A broad, rapid rise in prices spells trouble.
description: Prices in June climbed 9.1 percent from a year earlier, the fastest pace since 1981, as soaring gas prices, rising rents and swelling grocery bills made everyday life more expensive for American households. The pickup in prices was broad and faster than expected, spelling trouble for the Federal Reserve.
content: Prices in June climbed 9.1 percent from a year earlier, the fastest pace since 1981, as soaring gas prices, rising rents and swelling grocery bills made everyday life more expensive for American households. The pickup in prices was broad and faster than expected, spelling trouble for the Federal Reserve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Elite Colleges’ Quiet Fight to Favor Alumni Children
description: Colleges like Yale and Harvard give a boost to legacy applicants. But with affirmative action under attack, that tradition may become harder to defend.
content: Describing its incoming class of 2025, Yale boasted that its students hailed from 48 states, 68 countries and 1,221 high schools. What’s more, the university announced last year, 51 percent of the class identified as students of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Beauty of the Old Course Upstages LIV Golf Angst, for Now
description: Seven years is an unusually long gap, but the R&A, which runs the British Open, delayed a return to St. Andrews to ensure that it could host the tournament’s 150th edition, which begins Thursday.
content: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The ruins of St. Andrews’s once-majestic cathedral are a reminder that this gray town by the sea was a pilgrimage site long before golf came along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geoffrey Kabaservice
title: Why Do So Many Republicans Tolerate Donald Trump?
description: Mark Leibovich’s “Thank You for Your Servitude” asks why establishment Republicans failed to prevent a hostile takeover of their party.
content: In June 2017, the New York Times chief national correspondent Mark Leibovich visited the White House and was unexpectedly ushered into the Oval Office, where he found President Donald Trump watching (what else?) “Fox & Friends.” Trump issued a perfunctory denunciation of Leibovich’s then-employer and launched into his familiar litany of grievances and obsessions. “I had heard this all before,” Leibovich reflected later, “and was ready for it to end after about two minutes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall, Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
title: Chaos Engulfs Sri Lanka as Protesters Demand Ouster of Interim Leader
description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa fled, protesters angered by an economic meltdown overran the interim leader’s offices, and it was unclear who, if anyone, was in charge.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Sri Lanka descended into political chaos Wednesday, as the unpopular president fled the country and protesters overran the interim leader’s offices, leaving it unclear who held power or how long it would last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Bob Odenkirk, Five-Time Emmy Nominee, Isn’t Ready to Get Off the Ride
description: The star of “Better Call Saul” discussed his latest nod and bringing some measure of self-awareness to the character for his final bow.
content: For his final run starring in “Better Call Saul,” AMC’s critically adored “Breaking Bad” prequel, Emmy voters gave Bob Odenkirk an impressive parting gift — his fifth lead actor nomination in the show’s six seasons. “Saul,” which will conclude on Aug. 15 (it returned earlier this week after a break), earned seven nominations in total, including for best drama series and, for Odenkirk’s co-star, Rhea Seehorn, supporting actress in a drama series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Dollar Has Muscled Higher While the Euro Lost Ground
description: Why? Part of the answer is interest rates.
content: A $1 bill and a one-euro coin are worth almost exactly the same amount, for the first time in 20 years. The euro has traded above the dollar since 2002, but according to pricing sources tracked by Bloomberg, on Wednesday the euro, used by 19 nations, briefly fell below the buck, touching a low of $0.9998 before rebounding to $1.003 in afternoon trading in London. The dollar has been muscling higher against a broad range of currencies while the euro has been losing ground, especially against the dollar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: Sunlit Apocalypse: The Imperiled World of Robert Adams
description: In a magisterial survey at the National Gallery of Art, the photographer discerns poetry even in degraded Western landscapes.
content: WASHINGTON — Robert Adams photographs the landscapes of the contemporary American West, no matter how degraded, with the loving attention that his artistic forebears, Timothy H. O’Sullivan and Carleton E. Watkins, bestowed on sublime vistas in the 19th century. To borrow the words of the Polish poet Adam Zagajewski, he tries “to praise the mutilated world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer and Brian X. Chen
title: In a Post-Roe World, the Future of Digital Privacy Looks Even Grimmer
description: The sheer amount of tech tools and knowledge required to discreetly seek an abortion underlines how wide open we are to surveillance.
content: Welcome to the post-Roe era of digital privacy, a moment that underscores how the use of technology has made it practically impossible for Americans to evade ubiquitous tracking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Funding for Penn Station Plan Could Fall $3 Billion Short, Report Says
description: A new report, commissioned by an Albany watchdog group, is the latest volley in an intensifying debate over one of the nation’s most ambitious development projects.
content: New York’s plan for renovating and expanding Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan will  produce only enough revenue to cover about half of the improvements to the shabby station, a new financial analysis concluded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: The Case for Grilling Cucumbers
description: The cucumber’s fresh crunch has gone, but in its place is something more substantial to deliver a smoky, savory flavor.
content: There’s nothing more pointless, you might say, than grilling a cucumber. For all the things competing for space on the grill this summer, it’s the sausages and steak, surely, we expect to see sizzle. If not meat, then it’s whole fish or fish fillets that should be grilled, isn’t it? These are the things that, generally speaking, need to be cooked to be eaten, that need to undergo the transformation that the heat under the grill creates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: A Helicopter Crashed on a Tractor. Its Operator Saved the Pilot.
description: The young man was working in a cherry orchard in Washington State when he heard two thumps and looked up. A chopper was coming straight at him.
content: A 19-year-old man was operating a tractor in a cherry orchard in Washington State last week when, seemingly out of nowhere, a helicopter fell on him. Within minutes, he was able to free himself from the wreckage and save the pilot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Math Defeated Him in School. In His 60s, He Went Back for More.
description: In “A Divine Language,” Alec Wilkinson writes about the year he spent trying to learn the algebra, geometry and calculus that had confounded him decades before.
content: Writing a book is hard enough, so authors will sometimes use it as a chance to embark on something they have always wanted to do — take up dance, learn to juggle, travel the world, have more sex. The longtime New Yorker writer Alec Wilkinson took a decidedly different tack, choosing instead to chronicle his sustained efforts to do something he knew he hated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Alan Feuer
title: Jan. 6 and the Search for Direct Trump Links
description: The House panel investigating the Capitol riot has yet to find a proverbial smoking gun directly connecting the former president to the extremist groups that led the storming of the building. Is there one?
content: The House panel investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, assault on the Capitol held another blockbuster hearing on Tuesday, which featured previously unseen texts and draft social media posts suggesting that Donald Trump and his aides tried to make the march on the Capitol appear spontaneous even though they knew they were guiding a mob that was likely to turn violent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Police Arrest Owner of South African Tavern Where 21 Teenagers Died
description: Two employees were also arrested. Investigators have yet to say what killed the teenagers, who were found one June night collapsed in an overcrowded bar.
content: JOHANNESBURG — The owner and two employees of a tavern in South Africa where 21 teenagers were found dead under mysterious circumstances last month have been arrested and charged with selling alcohol to minors, the police said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Pete Wells’s Search for the Perfect Bite
description: Over a working dinner, the restaurant critic discussed his philosophy and what still excited him after 10 years on the job.
content: On a sunny, warm Thursday evening in Bushwick, Brooklyn, across the street from a vintage furniture store and next to a locally owned thrift shop, Pete Wells walked into Eyval, a Persian restaurant, for the second time.

title: Hawaii, the last state with an indoor mask mandate for public schools, will make masks optional.
description: Masks will become optional in Hawaii’s schools when the new academic year starts on Aug. 1, as the state tries for “a more normal classroom experience this fall,” a state health official said.
content: Hawaii has stuck with mask mandates longer than any other state. It waited until late March, when the first Omicron surge was receding, to drop its requirement for most indoor public settings — and even then, the requirement was retained for public schools.

title: Protesters take over the prime minister’s office and state broadcaster.

author: By Yasmine Farouk
title: Joe Biden Has a Saudi Problem
description: Biden’s visit to the kingdom is a personal defeat. But it does not have to be a defeat for the U.S.-Saudi relationship.
content: Bashing Saudi Arabia during a presidential election season is almost a tradition in the United States, and President Biden made no exception. Emboldened by domestic outrage over the murder of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi and the Saudi-led intervention in Yemen, Mr. Biden went further than his predecessors by calling Saudi Arabia a “pariah” state. That was miscalculated.

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Pope Names First Women to Office That Helps Select Bishops
description: The three women will serve five-year terms in the Vatican office that vets candidates, enhancing the role of women in the church’s operations.
content: Pope Francis on Wednesday appointed women for the first time to the office that advises him in the choice of bishops across the globe, a move that bolsters efforts to give women a larger voice in the church’s operations.

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: N.F.L. Players Pay a Small Price When Accused of Violence Against Women
description: A peer-reviewed study found that players who are arrested in these cases generally do not suffer major career consequences.
content: How the N.F.L. responds to accusations of violence against women has been discussed anecdotally for years, usually focusing on the short-term punishment individual athletes did or did not receive from their teams or the league. author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Soared in June, Pinching Consumers and Challenging Policymakers
description: Prices climbed 9.1 percent from a year earlier, ramping up pressure on the Federal Reserve to continue raising interest rates.
content: Prices surged 9.1 percent in June as consumers faced rapidly rising costs for gas, food and rent, a higher-than-expected reading and bad news for Americans at a moment when their wages are falling further behind the nation’s soaring cost of living.

author: By Dani Blum
title: You Won’t Live Longer by Diet or Exercise Alone, Study Says
description: Sprawling new research showed that healthy eating and regular workouts do not, in isolation, stave off later health issues. They need to be done together.
content: Health food or exercise alone isn’t enough to prevent chronic disease, new research shows. Contrary to popular belief, you can’t outrun the toll of a poor diet — and healthy eating, on its own, won’t ward off disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko, Téa Kvetenadze and Karen Zraick
title: Rescuer Describes Passengers’ Terror After Boat Capsized in Hudson River
description: A ferry captain who saved a woman said he would not forget the scene. Lindelia Vasquez, 47, and Julian Vasquez, 7, died in the accident.
content: The captain of the ferry that rescued a woman from a boat that capsized in the Hudson River, killing two people, said Wednesday that the scene of terror would become an indelible memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: U.S.C. Sex Scandals and the Paper That Tried to Cover Them Up
description: In 2016, editors at The Los Angeles Times were reluctant to publish reporting that would portray the university and its top fund-raisers in a negative light.
content: “Bad City,” by Paul Pringle, begins in Pasadena, Calif., in March 2016, with the kind of tip that reporters prize: An unconscious young woman. A drug-paraphernalia-strewn hotel room. An older male companion, reluctant to call for help, who turns out to be the dean of the University of Southern California’s prestigious Keck School of Medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: Biden, Battered at Home, Basks in Unvarnished Praise in Israel
description: The U.S. president, on the first day of a trip to the Mideast, received the sort of rapturous welcome he can only dream about in Washington.
content: JERUSALEM — If President Biden’s arrival in Israel on Wednesday for his first trip here since taking office could be summarized in just two words, they might be: Donald who?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Where the Crawdads Sing’ Review: A Wild Heroine, a Soothing Tale
description: Daisy Edgar-Jones stars as an orphaned girl in the marshes of North Carolina in this tame adaptation of Delia Owens’s popular novel.
content: “Where the Crawdads Sing,” Delia Owens’s first novel, is one of the best-selling fiction books in recent years, and if nothing else the new movie version can help you understand why.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Studies Probe Adenovirus Link to Childhood Hepatitis Cases
description: Two new papers add to the circumstantial evidence that a common childhood virus might be involved in the rare hepatitis cases, but many questions remain.
content: For months, scientists around the world have been investigating cases of severe, unexplained hepatitis, or liver inflammation, in previously healthy children. At least 920 probable cases have been detected in 33 countries since October, according to the World Health Organization. About 5 percent have required liver transplants, and 18 deaths have been reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Euro Falls to Equal the U.S. Dollar for the First Time in 20 Years
description: In recent months, pressure on the euro has been mounting while investors have been flocking to the U.S. dollar, a haven in times of economic upheaval.
content: Take a look: €1 = $1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: In Designing ‘The Sea Beast,’ Animators Sweat the Details
description: A deep dive into the look of the title character in the animated Netflix film.
content: Thanks to Covid-19 tests, it’s normal for somebody to have become intimately familiar with the interior of the human nose in the last couple of years. But in doing research for his new animated movie, the director Chris Williams dove deeper into nostrils than most of us have.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lily Puckett
title: In Portugal, Taking a Dive Into Sardines
description: The canned fish are having a moment in the food world. A tour of a canning factory in Porto gives an up-close view of a century-old business.
content: All vacation is in some way an observation of other people working while you do not. A stay at a hotel bears witness to maids and hosts; dinner sees chefs, busboys and waiters; an excursion requires a tour guide, a driver, a boat mechanic if you’re lucky. But there’s a peculiarity in going to a working factory to stand on a raised platform watching locals do hard, old-fashioned work, while you escape your own job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘The Killer’ Review: Stylistic Action Without the Heart
description: In this South Korean film, a teenage girl kidnapped by human traffickers brings an assassin out of retirement to save her.
content: It was only days ago that the retired assassin Ui-gang (Jang Hyuk) was enjoying a happy life with his wife (Bang Eun-jung). Now, after the kidnapping of a girl in the director Choi Jae-hoon’s muscular action flick “The Killer,” Ui-gang is facing down a barrage of goons in a narrow hallway to rescue her. He doesn’t flinch when an ax whizzes past his ear. Instead, with unblinking precision, he tears through two would-be killers while a shocked group of tough guys watch in fear from an elevator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Atul Loke and Victoria Kim
title: In Pictures: Sri Lanka’s Protesters Persist After President’s Departure
description: Many digesting the news of Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s exit appeared to relish witnessing a monumental day in the country’s history.
content: The abrupt departure of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka early Wednesday did little to quell the ire of protesters who have been filling the streets of the capital, Colombo, for months demanding his resignation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach St. George
title: Can Planting a Trillion New Trees Save the World?
description: To fight climate change, companies and nonprofits have been promoting worldwide planting campaigns. Getting to a trillion is easier said than done.
content: On a hot morning in April, near the start of Brazil’s dry season, four women and two men walked single file across a sodden field at the edge of Engenho, a village in the northern part of Goiás State. They wore long sleeves and wide-brimmed hats to protect against the sun, and leather gaiters and gloves to protect against snakes. In a plastic tub, they carried an entire forest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: At Yad Vashem, Israel’s Holocaust memorial, a reaffirmation of life.
description: President Biden met two survivors on a visit to Israel’s official Holocaust memorial in Jerusalem.
content: JERUSALEM — A long line of international dignitaries have paid visits to Yad Vashem, Israel’s official Holocaust memorial in Jerusalem. Even for President Biden, his visit on Wednesday was not his first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Drug-Resistant Infections in Hospitals Soared During the Pandemic, C.D.C. Says
description: A new report says the havoc wrought by the coronavirus reversed gains made by health care facilities to combat deadly pathogens.
content: The spread of drug-resistant infections surged during the coronavirus pandemic, killing nearly 30,000 people in 2020 and upending much of the recent progress made in containing the spread of so-called superbugs, according to an analysis by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lora Kelley
title: Delta flew a plane from Heathrow to the U.S. just to deliver 1,000 pieces of stranded luggage.
description: The London airport’s capacity troubles because of staff shortages and soaring demand have contributed to delays, cancellations and lost bags.
content: A Delta Air Lines plane packed with luggage but no passengers was flown from Heathrow Airport in London to Detroit this week, a Delta spokesman said on Wednesday. The luggage belonged to Delta customers who had recently traveled through Heathrow and were separated from their bags because of travel disruptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan and Anna Grace Lee
title: A Rhode Island State Senator Wants You to #TwerkFor Justice
description: Tiara Mack’s TikTok video of her twerking at the beach went viral. Now, she is using that momentum to bring awareness to her political platform.
content: When news broke of the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade in June, State Senator Tiara Mack, Democrat of Rhode Island, decided to try a new way of raising awareness for abortion access: She created a TikTok account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: A Homeless Suspect Is Arrested in Stabbings of 3 Homeless Men
description: Trevon Murphy, 40, who a cousin said had a history of mental illness, was spotted by a correction officer near a Harlem park.
content: A 40-year-old homeless man was arrested Wednesday on murder and attempted murder charges in the stabbings of three homeless men in Manhattan, one fatally, the police said. The men were all sleeping outdoors when attacked over the course of the last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: After a Surprise Firing, University of Michigan Has a New President
description: Santa J. Ono will be the university’s first Asian American president. He will take the helm during a contentious time in higher education.
content: The University of Michigan announced on Wednesday that its next president would be Santa J. Ono, a biomedical researcher known for his leadership on college affordability and action against climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: With Tennis Style, It’s Hard to Ace the Classics
description: While Grand Slam season often forecasts men’s wear innovations, the elegance of a crisp white look is tough to beat.
content: For at least some watching Novak Djokovic win his seventh Wimbledon title and 21st Grand Slam crown on Sunday (surprising almost no one), there was one largely unacknowledged pleasure in the experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: ‘The thieves are running away’: Protesters flock to the capital from around Sri Lanka.
description: Security forces fired tear gas in an effort to disperse people. Families with young children were among those marching.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — As a swelling crowd demanded that Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe step down and protesters breached the gate of his office on Wednesday, security forces fired tear gas and a military helicopter circled overhead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Lynn
title: Edison, N.J.: A Diverse Suburb in a Convenient Location
description: The Middlesex County township is just an hour from Manhattan, with easy access to transportation and a thriving Asian community.
content: When Bhavesh Gala and Taral Shah lived on Staten Island, they relied on their families in India to send packages of their favorite foods. But since the couple, who immigrated to the United States in the early 2000s, moved to Edison, N.J., they no longer find themselves depending on the family pipeline for homegrown products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Tears, Screaming and Insults: Inside an ‘Unhinged’ Meeting to Keep Trump in Power
description: Even by the standards of the Trump White House, a meeting on Dec. 18, 2020, that was highlighted Tuesday by the Jan. 6 committee was extreme.
content: The meeting lasted for more than six hours, past midnight, and devolved into shouting that could be heard outside the room. Participants hurled insults and nearly came to blows. Some people left in tears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Hiba Yazbek
title: Biden sidesteps a request to meet the family of a slain journalist on his trip, risking Palestinian anger.
description: The State Department instead invited Shireen Abu Akleh’s family to Washington, according to a U.S. official and the journalist’s brother.
content: The Biden administration has sidestepped a request for a meeting between the U.S. president and the family of Shireen Abu Akleh, a prominent Palestinian American journalist who was killed while reporting in the occupied West Bank in May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Online Shopping Is Bananas Confusing
description: How much we buy online affects the whole economy, but right now there are lots of question marks.
content: The mantra of 2022 should really be: No one knows anything.

title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Surprisingly Tight Race
description: Despite Biden’s low approval ratings, Democrats are roughly tied with Republicans in the midterm polls. We explain why.
content: My colleague Nate Cohn, The Times’s chief political analyst, has spent a lot of time thinking about the changing politics of economic class in the U.S. College graduates used to favor Republicans, while blue-collar voters favored Democrats. Increasingly, though, the opposite is true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: The Maldives may not be the Sri Lankan leader’s last stop.
description: For deposed leaders, the choice of where to hole up after being ousted can be determined by a number of factors, including historical and political ties between the countries, and, for some, extradition treaties.
content: About 24 hours before the president of Sri Lanka fled to the Maldives on Wednesday, his younger brother, the finance minister, made his own attempt to leave the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Elvis’ vs. Elvis
description: How much do fantasy and imagination play into how we remember pop culture heroes?
content: The Baz Luhrmann biopic “Elvis” has been one of this summer’s box office success stories, demonstrating the ongoing appetite for stories about Elvis Presley, one of pop music’s dynamic and contentious figures, as well as the cinematic power of Luhrmann’s vivid, overwhelming style, which is optimized for the big screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: In a New Census, Dance/NYC Wants to Count Every Dance Worker
description: The nonprofit organization’s goal is to establish labor standards across the industry, which was hard hit by the pandemic.
content: Dance/NYC, a nonprofit organization that promotes knowledge and appreciation of dance in New York City, is on a mission to count every dance worker — from choreographers to ballet teachers to Colombian folkloric dancers — and dance organization in New York City and its surrounding areas. The census will be among the largest undertakings of its kind in the performing arts, the organization said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Sri Lanka’s acting president has a long, and complicated, political history.
description: A prime minister six times over, Ranil Wickremesinghe’s leadership has been equated with Sri Lanka’s economic ambitions as well as its collapse.
content: Ranil Wickremesinghe was named acting president of Sri Lanka on Wednesday, after President Gotabaya Rajapaksa fled with his wife to the Maldives overnight.

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Victoria’s Secret and What’s Sexy Now
description: A rebranding and a new documentary have the lingerie company back in the cultural cross hairs.
content: When Victoria’s Secret announced, back in August 2021, that it was rebranding after years of falling sales and falling cultural credibility — that it would become a champion of female empowerment, replacing its bevy of supermodel angels with the VS Collective, ten women of great accomplishment as well as varying ages and body types — the news was met, generally (and understandably), with raised eyebrows.

title: How to Bulgogi Your Tofu
description: You don’t always need a recipe.
content: Good morning. I may hawk recipes in this space, but I don’t always use them. That’s especially true in the middle of the week when I’m ground down by the realities of a working life and don’t have a moment to browse our app. Time sneaks up on me, and suddenly it occurs to me that dinner needs to be made.
source.name: The New York Times
